仰观宇宙之大
俯察品类之盛
所以游目骋怀
足以极视听之娱
信可乐也1 Figure 1
Figure 1 sketches the basic hypothesis of the author’s theory. In the hypothesis, Q is the source point that emits spherical waves2constantly in the universe while P is the field point in considerable distance that receive electromagnetic waves emitted by Q.
Suppose both Q and P can be described in space rectangular coordinate system as follows.$$Q(x_0,y_0,0)\tag{1}$$$$P(x,y,z)\tag{2}$$$$\left|PQ\right|=r\tag{3}$$
Q is the source point that emits spherical waves, which can be described as $$\vec{E}(P)=\frac{A}{\vec{r}}\exp{(\mathrm{i}k\vec{r})}\tag{4}$$ Suppose A=1 in (4) and E, r are scalar, we have$$E(P)=\frac{1}{r}\exp{(\mathrm{i}kr)}\tag{5}$$ According to the Pythagorean theorem, r can be described as $$r=\sqrt{(x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2+z^2}$$$$r=z\sqrt{\frac{(x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2}{z^2}+1}$$ With the help of binomial expansion, we have$$r=z (1+\frac{(x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2}{2z^2}-\frac{[(x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2]^2}{8z^4}+\cdots ) \tag{6}$$ Given the paraxial condition, we have$$z^2\gg [(x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2]_{\max}\tag{7}$$ Given the far-field condition, we have$$k \frac{x^2+y^2}{2z} \ll \pi $$$$k \frac{x_0^2+y_0^2}{2z} \ll \pi $$i.e.$$\frac{x^2+y^2}{2z}\ll \frac{\lambda}{2}\tag{8}$$$$\frac{x_0^2+y_0^2}{2z}\ll \frac{\lambda}{2}\tag{9}$$ 2 parts in (5) with different colours are displayed below.$$E(P)=\frac{1}{\color{pink}r}\exp(\mathrm{i}k{\color{lightblue}r})$$ In that the wave number k of red light is large, we take zero order approximation to the pink part and first order approximation to the lightblue part. And (9) is also the result of paraxial condition. $$E(P)=\frac{1}{\color{pink}z}\exp \mathrm{i}k\left[ {\color{lightblue}z+\frac{(x-x_0)^2+(y-y_0)^2}{2z}} \right] \tag{10}$$ In view of$$xx_0\ll z\tag{11}$$$$yy_0\ll z\tag{12}$$ we can derive (13) from (8), (9), (11) and (12).$$E(P)=\frac{1}{z}\exp (\mathrm{i}kz)\tag{13}$$ Above expression (13) of spherical waves in Q is the form of plane wave. We come to the conclusion that spherical waves under paraxial and far-field conditions can be approximately regarded as plane wave.
  The above quote is excerpted from Xizhi Wang’s Preface to the Orchid Pavilion Collection in A.D.353. ↩︎
 Spherical waves are essentially electromagnetic waves in the context above. ↩︎
title: [Theory] Spherical Waves under Paraxial and Far-Field Conditions

And that has made all the difference.1 你好！FANG META! 谨此纪念 FANG META! 的诞生。
（附上一首歌） FANG META! 的创造过程 FANG META! 是 FANG 在 2022 年初隔离期间过于无聊摸鱼创造的。
FANG 在创造 FANG META! 之前曾尝试使用 HTML5 模板（曾经的 FANG PAGE! ）和 Hexo 搭建平台，但因这样或那样的原因，中国内地地区并不能完整地加载页面。
所以。。弃坑了（并没有
 然而有一天， FANG 在路边捡到一只大佬，Chtholist  。
Chtholist  ：“不会吧不会吧不会还有人在用 Hexo 吧？？？”（言外之意用 HUGO ）
———“好的，这就换 HUGO 。”
在此感谢Chtholist  sama 为 FANG META! 的诞生提供的技术援助。ありがとうございます！
 在原有的 git 环境基础上， FANG 按照知乎等平台 （除 CSDN 之外） 提供的安装教程，很快完成了 HUGO 的部署。
接着借助作者Jimmy  提供的 Stack 主题，顺利完成 FANG META! 的搭建。
最后经过一番折腾配置，就有了您所看到的这些页面。
目前 FANG META! 还有部分功能逐步完善中。
“ Anyway, FANG META! is always here for FANG, still, for YOU! ”
About HUGO Written in Go, Hugo is an open source static site generator available under the Apache Licence 2.0. Hugo supports TOML, YAML and JSON data file types, Markdown and HTML content files and uses shortcodes to add rich content. Other notable features are taxonomies, multilingual mode, image processing, custom output formats, HTML/CSS/JS minification and support for Sass SCSS workflows.
Hugo makes use of a variety of open source projects including:
 https://github.com/yuin/goldmark https://github.com/alecthomas/chroma https://github.com/muesli/smartcrop https://github.com/spf13/cobra https://github.com/spf13/viper  Hugo is ideal for blogs, corporate websites, creative portfolios, online magazines, single page applications or even a website with thousands of pages.
Hugo is for people who want to hand code their own website without worrying about setting up complicated runtimes, dependencies and databases.
Websites built with Hugo are extremelly fast, secure and can be deployed anywhere including, AWS, GitHub Pages, Heroku, Netlify and any other hosting provider.
Learn more and contribute on GitHub.
